articles.headline: Standoff Over Payroll Tax Cut Leaves Wake of Uncertainty
articles.snippet: By turning down a bill that was supported by both parties in the Senate as well as the White House, the conservative House majority is now staring over the brink.
articles.abstract: By turning down a bill that was supported by both parties in the Senate as well as the White House, the conservative House majority is now staring over the brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After defiantly rejecting a Senate compromise to extend a payroll tax break and jobless pay, Speaker John A. Boehner stood before the television cameras on Tuesday enveloped by scores of House Republicans. Even as a group, they seemed very much alone.

articles.headline: Looking to Streamline Airport Security Screenings
articles.snippet: With global air traffic growing about 5 percent a year, industry executives and security experts say a fundamental rethinking of security checkpoints is inevitable.
articles.abstract: With global air traffic growing about 5 percent a year, industry executives and security experts say a fundamental rethinking of security checkpoints is inevitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Travelers in the midst of another holiday season of shuffling shoeless through seemingly interminable airport security lines may find it difficult to imagine a future where screenings are not only speedy but thorough.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Fed Proposes New Capital Rules for Banks
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s plan for capital and liquidity requirements would be introduced in two phases and would not be likely to go beyond international standards.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s plan for capital and liquidity requirements would be introduced in two phases and would not be likely to go beyond international standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Tuesday proposed rules that would require the largest American banks to hold more capital — and to keep it more easily accessible — to protect against another financial crisis.

articles.headline: In Canada, a Car Built in China
articles.snippet: For the first time, cars built in China are arriving in North America, with Honda importing its subcompact Fit into Canada.
articles.abstract: For the first time, cars built in China are arriving in North America, with Honda importing its subcompact Fit into Canada.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Chinese-made cars have quietly arrived in North America for the first time, but without the bamboo dashboards and quirky names that have adorned them at recent auto shows.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Ian Austen

articles.headline: A Fight to Make Banks More Prudent
articles.snippet: Regulators want banks to finance their operations with more capital and less borrowed money, but that means less profits and lower bonuses.
articles.abstract: Regulators want banks to finance their operations with more capital and less borrowed money, but that means less profits and lower bonuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — For Philipp M. Hildebrand, it was a reminder of what happens when you get between bankers and their bonuses.

articles.headline: For Gingrich in Power, Pragmatism, Not Purity
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich’s years as a House Republican leader created distrust among some conservatives who view him as too much of a pragmatist.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich’s years as a House Republican leader created distrust among some conservatives who view him as too much of a pragmatist.

articles.headline: Few Options for Lagging T-Mobile
articles.snippet: The wireless carrier is struggling, with a dwindling subscriber base, weak finances and no obvious way out after the deal with AT&T was scuttled.
articles.abstract: The wireless carrier is struggling, with a dwindling subscriber base, weak finances and no obvious way out after the deal with AT&T was scuttled.
articles.lead_paragraph: T-Mobile USA, the weaker partner in the now-collapsed proposed merger with AT&T, has few good options to thrive in the competitive wireless market in the United States.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Carbon Emission Fees for Flights Upheld
articles.snippet: A decision by the European Union’s highest court on Wednesday could spark a trade war with countries that oppose being forced into Europe’s carbon-trading system.
articles.abstract: A decision by the European Union’s highest court on Wednesday could spark a trade war with countries that oppose being forced into Europe’s carbon-trading system.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Union’s highest court on Wednesday endorsed the bloc’s plan to begin charging the world’s biggest airlines for their greenhouse gas emissions starting Jan. 1. The move sets the stage for a potentially costly trade war with the United States, China and other countries.

articles.headline: European Bank in Strong Move to Loosen Credit
articles.snippet: After long resisting the kind of force Washington used at the height of the financial crisis in 2008, Europe’s central bankers pumped nearly $640 billion into its banking system.
articles.abstract: After long resisting the kind of force Washington used at the height of the financial crisis in 2008, Europe’s central bankers pumped nearly $640 billion into its banking system.
articles.lead_paragraph: After long resisting the kind of financial force Washington used at the height of the financial crisis in 2008, European central bankers on Wednesday pumped nearly $640 billion into the Continent’s banking system. The move raised hopes that the money could alleviate the region’s credit squeeze.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and David Jolly

articles.headline: Army Charges 8 in Wake of Death of a Fellow G.I.
articles.snippet: The American military said it had charged eight soldiers in Pvt. Danny Chen’s battalion in connection with his death in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The American military said it had charged eight soldiers in Pvt. Danny Chen’s battalion in connection with his death in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: One night in October, an Army private named Danny Chen apparently angered his fellow soldiers by forgetting to turn off the water heater after taking a shower at his outpost in Afghanistan, his family said.

articles.headline: Prime Minister Puts Power-Sharing at Risk in Iraq
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s threat to abandon a year-old power-sharing government added to his fragile democracy’s turmoil just after the exit of American troops.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s threat to abandon a year-old power-sharing government added to his fragile democracy’s turmoil just after the exit of American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq threatened on Wednesday to abandon an American-backed power-sharing government created a year ago, throwing a fragile democracy into further turmoil just after the departure of American troops and potentially tarnishing what has been cast as a major foreign policy achievement for President Obama.
